abstract.p: We consider the response of a linear structural system when coupled to an attachment containing strong or even essential nonlinearities. For this system, the attachment, designated as a nonlinear energy sink, is designed as a nonlinear vibration absorber, serving to dissipate energy from the structural system. Moreover, the attachment not only leads to a reduction in the total energy of the system, but also nonlinearly couples together the vibration modes of the linear structural system. When the structure is impulsively loaded, the nonlinear energy sink serves to both dissipate and redistribute energy, thus enhancing the observed structural dissipation. The effect of the nonlinear attachment on the linear primary system can be quantified in terms of equivalent measures for the damping and frequency of each mode, derived through consideration of the instantaneous energy balance in each mode. The influence of the nonlinear energy sink on the structural response is illustrated with an impulsively forced two-degree-of-freedom primary system, representing a two-story structure, with different types of nonlinear energy sink attached to the top floor. We perform optimization studies in order to design the nonlinear energy sink for optimal shock mitigation of the primary system. The proposed methodology is based only on measured time series without resorting to frequency analysis. As such, it is valid for strongly nonlinear systems as well as for systems with nonsmooth nonlinearities, and is suited to both simulated and experimental results. Finally, an experimental validation of the enhanced dissipation introduced by the nonlinear energy sink is provided, and the experimental response is compared against numerical simulation of the corresponding analytical model to illustrate the effectiveness of the nonlinear energy sink design. Thus, we analytically predict and experimentally verify the efficacy of the nonlinear energy sink to significantly reduce the response of the two degree-of-freedom system subject to shock excitation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Traditional structural systems are often designed with either high stiffness or large damping, as typical engineering materials possess one of these characteristics, but not both. Recently, the addition of components with strong nonlinearities has been shown to provide a mechanism that enables efficient energy transfer, and has recently come under investigation in the context of targeted energy transfer (TET).1–3 In this, strongly nonlinear attachments, referred to as nonlinear energy sinks (NESs), are added to a linear primary system with the purpose of enhancing the transfer and dissipation of energy within the structure. The performance of the NES has been illustrated through analysis, simulation, and experimental work.4–7 This enhanced energy transfer has been shown to arise from transient resonance capture between the linear structural modes and the strongly nonlinear attachment.8–10

The effect of structural nonlinearities can be interpreted in terms of their effect on the traditional linear stiffness and damping parameters. For example, a cubic stiffness nonlinearity with positive cubic coefficient is often referred to as ‘hardening’,11 as the frequency of oscillation for a system with this nonlinearity increases as the energy in the system increases. This trend mimics the behavior of a linear system with increasing stiffness, hence a hardening effect with increasing energy. For weakly nonlinear systems, standard perturbation techniques such as the method of multiple scales can describe this behavior and capture these hardening effects. More recently, a number of works considered the role of strong nonlinearities on the behavior of systems through a complexification/averaging procedure.12,13

While the role of stiffness nonlinearities has received much attention, the influence of nonlinearities on the energy dissipation within a structure has received much less consideration. Hence, the NESs, which are local components, can induce global nonlinear effects in the dynamics of the structures to which they are attached. When properly designed, an NES can significantly enhance the dissipation observed in the linear primary structure. However, this process requires a measure of the overall effect of the NES on the damping within the linear structure. This study illustrates recently developed measures of modal damping and frequency for linear structural modes in the presence of NESs.14 These measures, based on energetic considerations, are applied to time-series data and can be used to quantify the effectiveness of nonlinear attachments on the response of linear structural systems.

These measures and subsequent optimization are applied to a two degree-of-freedom linear primary system, coupled to three different types of NESs. The first, denoted as a Type-I NES, is composed of a single degree-of-freedom attachment with an essential stiffness nonlinearity and linear damping between the structure and the attachment. The second, a Type-II NES, is again a single degree-of-freedom attachment with an essential stiffness nonlinearity. However, the dissipation is represented by nonlinear damping. Finally, a Type-III NES corresponds to a two degree-of-freedom attachment with essential nonlinearities between both the structure and attachment, as well as between the internal NES masses. In this final configuration, the damping is once again represented by linear viscous damping. In each configuration, the effective damping is determined and the NES parameters are then optimized to maximize the observed energy dissipation in the dominant mode of the structure.

These numerical and analytical results are validated through a series of experimental tests with a two degree-of-freedom lightly damped primary system possessing two floors, with an essentially nonlinear attachment on the top floor. Moreover, experimental damped transitions are depicted in frequency–energy plots, and the observed dynamical behavior corresponds to the analytical results determined from the corresponding theoretical model.

sec.title: General equations of motion
sec.p: We consider a multi-degree-of-freedom structural system, described by linear equations of motion in terms of physical coordinates x, coupled to strongly non-linear attachments, where the ith attachment is described by the coordinates ui. The dimensional equations of motion for the linear structural system will then be transformed to modal coordinates q. Finally, the system can be nondimensionalized and expressed in terms of the nondimensional modal coordinates p and NES coordinates wi.

sec.title: Effective parameters
sec.p: For this system, the NES serves to dissipate energy from the structural system in a one-way nearly irreversible fashion through targeted energy transfer. It follows that the attachment not only leads to a reduction in the total energy of the system, but also couples together the linear structural modes, thereby allowing for energy to also be redistributed among these structural modes of the system. The effect of the nonlinear attachment on the linear primary system can be quantified in terms of equivalent measures for the damping and frequency of each mode, derived through consideration of the instantaneous energy contained in each mode. These equivalent measures have been recently developed by Sapsis et al,14 and are briefly reviewed here.

sec.title: Frequency–energy plots
sec.p: As discussed in previous works,16 the response of the lightly damped structure closely follows the underlying dynamics of the undamped Hamiltonian system. In particular, at a given energy of the undamped system, nonlinear normal modes (NNMs)17 can be determined and parameterized by the inverse of their fundamental period, which provides a measure of their fundamental frequency. The resulting frequency–energy plots (FEPs) map the locations of the NNMs in the frequency–energy plane. For the damped system, the energy is no longer constant and instead decays in time, thus, no periodic solutions exist. However, the instantaneous frequency content of the response can be identified through a wavelet transform. When this instantaneous frequency distribution is shown as a function of the energy, the system follows the structure of the FEPs of the undamped system. The addition of light damping to the Hamiltonian system provides a mechanism for transitions from one branch of the FEP, or family of NNMs, to another as energy is dissipated.

Frequency–energy plots of systems with NES attachments were numerically computed using a shooting procedure and a method for continuation of NNM motions developed by Peeters et al.18 The procedure was initiated by providing a guess or approximate initial state, s(0)≡(x(0),x·(0)) and period T0 that will produce a periodic response. The system employing the approximate initial state and period was numerically integrated to find the state at the end of the period, and then refined using a Newton–Raphson iteration scheme until the error, ‖s(T) − s(0)‖, was adequately reduced. It follows that s(0) represents the initial state of an NNM with period T. A continuation method was then used to provide an approximate initial state for a nearby NNM so that it may be refined. The adaptive-step-size continuation method utilized a pseudo-arclength method for advancing the solution, and the step size was controlled by the number of Newton iterations required for the solution to converge.

For most systems, scaling the linearized modes to sufficiently low energy produces an adequate initial guess to start the continuation procedure. However, due to the essential nonlinearity of the NES, its linearized frequency is zero, so it is common practice to add a small linear component to the nonlinear stiffness. This introduces a small, nonzero eigenvalue to the system which provides an initial estimate of the period for a low-energy NNM. For systems with multiple backbone curves, though, additional initial guesses are required. These were determined by reintroducing damping into the system and numerically simulating for a variety of relevant initial conditions. The wavelet transform (frequency of the signal as a function of time) of the response was then superimposed on the partial FEP to determine if it followed any `new' branches. If a new branch was located, that portion of the damped response could be isolated to approximate the initial state and period of an NNM on that branch.

As a final step, the stability of each NNM was studied using Floquet theory in a procedure that is described in detail by Peeters et al.18 However, numerical error is inherent in the initial states and periods for NNMs and in the numerical integration required to determine the Floquet multipliers. Thus, this numerical application of Floquet theory works well for locating regions of stability or instability, but the location of transitions between stable and unstable NNMs cannot be reliably determined in many cases.

sec.title: Type I NES
sec.p: A Type I NES describes a single degree-of-freedom NES coupled to the second mass of the system through a cubic nonlinear spring in parallel with a linear viscous damper (Figure 1), so that (49) while the equation of motion for the attachment is (50)
For the nondimensional system, the equation of motion for the NES is given as (51) while the coupling force gNES is given as (52)
Notice that the addition of the NES through the force gNES couples together the response of the structural modes represented by p1 and p2.

Considering the nondimensional NES parameters (53) the response of the system is shown in Figure 2. Specifically, the modal displacements p1 and p2 are shown versus time, as well as the relative displacement between the NES and the primary system, defined as z(τ) = w1(τ) − y2(τ). For these initial conditions, the response is dominated by the fundamental mode. The energy in each structural mode is shown in Figure 3. The influence of the NES can be clearly observed when the evolution of the energy is compared to that in the absence of the attachment. The NES, if properly designed, can be used to significantly enhance the energy dissipation observed in the primary system. In Figure 3, the solid lines represent the modal energies versus time in the system with the NES, while the dashed curves illustrate the modal energies in the primary system without the attached NES. As expected, without the NES these energies decay exponentially in time and the decay rate can be determined exactly from the assumed proportional damping values. In contrast, the decay rate of these energies in the presence of the NES is no longer constant. The fundamental mode decays much faster while the energy in the second mode fluctuates. As noted above, the NES couples together the structural modes allowing energy to be both dissipated and exchanged among modes. The increases in energy observed in the second mode can be attributed to energy being transfered from the fundamental mode. Figure 2.
Type I NES: System response (μ = 0.05, β = 0.01; ℰ(0) = 0.0025); note the different vertical scale used in the response of p2. Figure 3.
Type I NES: Modal energy; ℰ(0) = 0.0025.

The modification to the structural response provided by the NES can be characterized in terms of the equivalent frequency and damping as described in equation (38). For the response illustrated in Figure 2, these equivalent measures are shown in Figures 4 and 5. In each figure, the solid line represents the instantaneous value of the effective quantity (frequency or damping), while the dashed curve describes the accumulated measure, as defined in equations (39) and (40). Both of these measures are shown relative to the intrinsic values of damping and frequency of the primary system for each mode. Figure 4.
Type I NES: Effective modal parameters (μ = 0.05, β = 0.01; ℰ(0) = 0.0025); Mode 1, ω1 = 0.523, λ1 = 0.0105. Figure 5.
Type I NES: Effective modal parameters (μ = 0.05, β = 0.01; ℰ(0) = 0.0025); Mode 2, ω2 = 1.44, λ2 = 0.0086.

For these initial conditions, the fundamental mode contains 96% of the initial energy and the resulting equivalent measures are shown in Figure 4. The effective frequency undergoes little variation in time, indicating that the attachment has only minimal influence on this quantity, so that ω1,⋆/ω1 = 0.95. This can be attributed in part to the small mass ratio chosen for this simulation. In contrast, the effective damping can significantly fluctuate. For the fundamental mode, it can reach a maximum value of λ(t)/λ1 = 6.30, while the global equivalent damping is λ1,⋆/λ1 = 3.88, indicating that the NES enhances the observed damping in the system by this factor.

The second mode thus contains only 4% of the initial energy and its equivalent measures are shown in Figure 5. Because of the low energy content of this mode, it is significantly affected by energy transfer from the dominant mode of the response, and the effective frequency and damping exhibit large-scale rapid fluctuations arising from this redistribution of energy. In fact, when this measure is negative the energy in this mode is increasing. However, the global effective damping of the second mode shows minimal contribution from the attachment, with λ2,⋆/λ2 = 0.87, primarily due to the initial energy transfer seen in Figure 9(b). As for the dominant fundamental mode, the global effective frequency is only slightly influenced by the NES, with ω2,⋆/ω2 = 0.99.

The above numerical simulations illustrate the ability of these effective measures of modal frequency and damping to represent the dynamic behavior of a linear structure under the influence of the nonlinear attachment. These measures can thus be used to characterize the response of the structure as the parameters of the NES vary and serve as suitable performance criteria for design optimization.

Recall that with the nondimensionalization described in `Nondimensional equations of motion' section, the nondimensional energy ℰ(0) is related to both the dimensional energy E(0) and the NES stiffness kNES. Thus, examining the variation of the system dynamics with ℰ(0) captures both the variation in the dimensional values of E(0) and kNES through equation (27). In Figure 6, for β = 0.01, the global effective damping ratios λ1,⋆/λ1 and λ2,⋆/λ2 are shown as the initial energy ℰ(0) varies. These effective measures depend on the initial energy because of the presence of the nonlinearity in the attachment. In contrast, if linear elements were used in the attachment, these effective measures would be independent of the initial energy. The fundamental mode shows a single peak in the global effective damping, while the second mode shows more variability. However, recall that the energy in the response is dominated by the fundamental mode, and as illustrated in Figure 5, the response of the second mode is sensitive to energy transfer between the linear modes and the NES. Figure 6.
Type I NES: Global effective damping λ⋆λ (μ = 0.05, β = 0.01); the dashed line corresponds to the initial energy used in Figures 2 to 5.

In Figure 7, this effective damping measure of the fundamental mode is shown for varying values of β, the NES damping coefficient. For both low and high levels of NES damping, the effective measure of damping for the system approaches the intrinsic structural damping in the system, so that λ1,⋆/λ1 ≈ 1. However, for an intermediate level of damping in the NES, the effect on the structural system is significant. As the damping is increased, the effective damping response broadens on the initial energy. In Figure 8, the global effective damping is shown as a function of both the initial energy and the NES damping coefficient β. From this, for fixed mass ratio the attachment stiffness and damping can be optimized to achieve a maximum value of this damping measure, which occurs for (54) Finally, in Figure 9, the decay of the energy in mode 1 is shown as the initial energy varies. In particular, note that for the optimally designed system, the energy in the fundamental mode is rapidly dissipated, while for energy levels above and below this value, the decay in energy is less rapid. We now focus on the frequency–energy plots of this system. As mentioned previously, the response of the lightly damped structure closely follows the underlying dynamics of the undamped system. In particular, at a given energy of the undamped system, periodic solutions can be determined, and the frequency of these periodic motions, identified as the inverse of the corresponding fundamental period, can be parameterized by the energy in the system. These frequency–energy plots, defined only for the undamped system, are shown in Figure 10. For the damped system, the energy is no longer constant and instead decays in time. Thus, no periodic solutions exist. However, the instantaneous frequency content of the response can be identified through a wavelet transform. When this instantaneous frequency distribution is shown as a function of the energy, the system follows the structure of the frequency–energy plots of the undamped system. Figure 10.
FEP of the nondimensional primary system coupled to a type I NES (μ = 0.05); insets represent the nondimensionalized physical displacement of selected periodic orbits.

The FEP of the primary system coupled to a type-I NES with μ = 0.05 is shown in Figure 10 with insets showing the nondimensional physical displacement of the system dofs for selected periodic orbits. When the response of the system is localized to the linear oscillator, the frequency remains nearly constant as the energy changes. This can be seen for relatively low energies at ω = 0.55 and ω = 1.45, when the primary system response is linear (i.e. it can be described as the superposition of the linear modes), and it is effectively uncoupled from the nonlinear attachment. These branches continue to zero energy, but they have been truncated in Figure 10. The backbone of the NES approaches zero frequency at low energy and increases in frequency as energy increases. Along the backbone the response, or energy, of the system is localized to the NES, which oscillates at a frequency equal to that of the primary systems. Emanating from the backbone are subharmonic tongues where internal resonance occurs between the NES and the first or second mode of the primary systems. The insets at ω = 0.175 and ω = 0.290 show subharmonic periodic orbits for 1:3 internal resonance with the first mode of the primary system and 1:5 internal resonance with the second mode, respectively. Finally, a periodic orbit for 5:1 superharmonic-resonance with mode one of the primary system is shown near ω = 0.55, ℰ = 0.1. In this representation of the FEP, only superharmonic tongues where resonance ratios are integers (i.e. 3:1, 5:1, 7:1, etc.) are shown, and they appear near the natural frequency of the linear mode with which internal resonance occurs. Additional superharmonic orbits with ratios like 3:2, 4:3, etc. are not shown in Figure 10.

In Figure 11, the wavelet transform of the response is shown superimposed on the FEP of the system for different initial energy levels. For values of ℰ(0) above and below the optimal level, shown in Figure 11(a) and (c), the dominant frequency of the response is primarily centered around the horizontal branches of the FEP near ω = 0.55, which corresponds to the NNM that is localized in the linear primary system (the extension of the fundamental linear mode). However, for the optimal energy level shown in Figure 11(b), with the most effective energy transfer, the wavelet plot shows that the frequency shifts with the decay in energy. Moreover, this response excites the NES leading to the observed energy transfer and dissipation properties. Note that the optimal case corresponds to the activation of the transition point in the FEP between the branches localized in the linear primary system and those that strongly excite the NES. The response of the system with a Type II NES is qualitatively similar to that of a Type I NES. Each is described as a single degree-of-freedom attachment, and the frequency–energy plots for the undamped systems are identical. As before, the response of the structure can be characterized by the effective damping and frequency identified in equation (41). In Figure 13, the effective damping is shown as the initial energy and damping in the NES are varied. Recall, that the stiffness of the NES has been nondimensionalized to unity. Comparing this with Figure 8, the region of enhanced dissipation is increased for the Type II NES compared to the Type I design. In addition, the optimal damping parameter is significantly larger than for the Type I attachment. This is to be expected from the nonlinear form of the NES damping. Given the quadratic dependence on the amplitude of the nonlinear damping term, larger coefficients are required to significantly influence the structural response. sec.title: Type III NES
sec.p:
A Type III NES describes a two degree-of-freedom NES coupled to the second mass of the system (Figure 15). Each of the springs in the NES is essentially nonlinear, while the NES damping is linear, so that Figure 15.

The nondimensional system is scaled by the equivalent stiffness of the NES, so that (63) Thus, the equation of motion for the NES is given as (64) (65) while the coupling force f∧NES 1 is given as (66)
With this nondimensionalization, the NES stiffnesses are related as (67)

The influence of the Type III NES on the linear primary system can again be studied through the effective modal damping and frequency. As with the Type I and II NESs, the effective frequency shows little change for the small mass ratios considered in this study. However, the Type III NES is shown to be very effective at reducing the energy within the primary system, thus significantly increasing the effective damping in the structure.

For a fixed total NES mass ratio of μ1 + μ2 = 0.05, the initial energy as well as the NES parameters can be chosen to maximize the effective damping. The NES parameters consist of the mass ratio μ1/μ2, the stiffness ratio κNES,1/κNES,2 and the two independent damping parameters βNES,1 and βNES,2. The optimization was performed with MATLAB's fmincon function, which applies a constrained nonlinear optimization algorithm to determine the optimal parameters based on maximizing the effective damping. For the primary system given in equations (47) and (48) with Type III NES, the optimal parameters are found to be (68)

The variation in the global effective damping with the NES parameters is seen in Figures 16 and 17. In Figure 16, the value of λ1,⋆ is shown as the initial energy ℰ(0) and βNES,2 vary. In this figure, the remaining parameters are set to their optimal values as given in equation (68). In this, there is a single maximum at the optimal parameter values for ℰ(0) and βNES,2, which leads to λ1,⋆ = 0.0554. In addition, if the damping is held fixed, a single local maximum is observed near this optimal energy level. Figure 16.
Type III NES: Global effective damping, mode 1 (μ1 = 0.039, μ2 = 0.011, κNES,1 = 12.2, κNES,2 = 5.54). Figure 17.
Type III NES: Global effective damping, mode 1 (ℰ(0) = 1.17 × 10−4, μ1 = 0.039, μ2 = 0.011, κNES,1 = 12.2, κNES,2 = 5.54).

Also note that the optimization algorithm found that the damping was localized in the second NES mass, so that βNES,1 ∼ 0. In Figure 17, the global effective damping is shown as βNES,1 and βNES,2 vary independently. Local maxima are achieved for either βNES,1 ∼ 0 or βNES,2 ∼ 0, so that the damping is concentrated in only one location.

With the added degree-of-freedom, the response of the type-III NES is much more varied than either the Type I or II configuration. In addition, as shown above, even with identical mass ratios of 0.05, the Type III NES leads to a significantly larger value for the global effective damping observed in the primary system.

The FEP of the nondimensional primary system coupled to a Type III NES with μ = 0.05 is shown in Figure 18. Insets show the nondimensional physical displacement of the system for selected periodic orbits. The FEP of the system with a Type III NES contains all of the features associated with the FEP of the system with a Type I NES. What makes it particularly unique is that it has multiple backbones which are possible because the Type III NES is composed of two coupled Type I NESs, allowing for the two masses to interact when the energy in the system is localized to the nonlinear dofs. For example, the orbits of the two lowest energy backbone curves are localized to the NES with the NES dofs out-of-phase at lower energy and in-phase at higher energy. These are the most relevant backbone curves for this discussion because they are the only stable motions localized to the NES. However, it is interesting to note that closely spaced backbone curves have been located along with a variety of internal resonances localized to the NES (see insets at high-energy backbones). Figure 18.
FEP of the nondimensional primary system coupled to a Type III NES (μ = 0.05); insets represent the nondimensionalized physical displacement of selected periodic orbits.

Finally, the wavelet transforms of the two NES masses, w1 and w2, are shown in Figure 19. The frequency content of these components is similar, and the optimal design is again able to activate branches of the FEP that are able to transfer energy from the linear primary structure to the NES. Figure 19.
Type III NES: Frequency–energy plots with superimposed wavelet transforms; optimal initial energy, ℰ(0) = 1.22 × 10−3.

sec.title: Experimental description
sec.p:
An experimental system has been developed that can be characterized as a scale model of a two-story structure. The system is designed to undergo displacement primarily in a single direction and an essentially nonlinear attachment, designated as NES, is attached to the upper mass (floor) as illustrated in Figure 20. Thus, the experimental system is well approximated by a two degree-of-freedom linear primary system subject to base excitation, with an essentially nonlinear NES attached to the upper floor. Figure 20.
Linear base structure with NES attached.

sec.title: Linear structure
sec.p: The base structure that the NES is attached to is designed to be linear under the applied excitations. This structure consists of two floor masses and a base plate connected by four spring steel columns and is shown in Figure 20 with the NES attached to the top floor. The floor masses and the base plate are 457.2 × 457.2 × 12.7 mm3 steel plates. The floor plates are appropriately detailed to attach the NES and the masses of floors 1 and 2 are 24.3 and 24.2 kg, respectively. The cross-section of the columns is 50.8 × 1.27 mm2 and there is a 203.2 mm clear span distance between each of the floors plates. These columns are orientated such that the weak axis of the column is in the direction of loading. With this orientation, the stiffness, and thus the natural frequencies of the motion, of the building perpendicular to the direction of the loading are much higher than in the direction parallel with the direction of loading. The columns are made out of high yield strength spring steel to ensure they have high displacement capacity without yielding.

Experimental modal analysis was performed to determine precise modal properties of the building in the as-built condition. To perform this analysis, the linear system without the NES attached was excited using the shake table and step function input, as described above. Data were collected on the acceleration response of base and two floors. With averaging, data from multiple trials were used to calculate the transfer functions from the base excitation to the floor responses. Additionally, exponential windowing of the time history data used for the transfer functions was utilized to reduce spectral leakage and help suppress any noise in the system.19 The MATLAB-based software MFDID20 was used to curve fit the experimental transfer functions and produce a mathematical model of the system. From this identified model, the natural frequencies of the system are 1.68 and 4.62 Hz. These identified mode shapes and natural frequencies in the as-built condition correspond quite well with predictions from the model of the system developed during its design, based on the equivalent column stiffnesses. Finally, the experimentally identified mass, damping, and stiffness matrices were those given previously in equation (42).

sec.title: Essentially nonlinear attachment
sec.p:
NES used in this experimental testing is seen in Figure 21. The mass of the NES moves along a rail in one direction, parallel with the direction of load, via internal linear roller bearings. This NES mass is adjustable with the removable mass plates; however, for these tests, the NES mass was fixed at 2.04 kg, or 4.2% of the moving mass of the linear structure. The restoring force applied to the NES is provided by a steel wire that is fed into the NES where it is internally clamped. The ends of this wire are fixed on metal blocks on each side of the NES. These blocks are positioned such that the NES exhibits the nonlinear stiffness characteristic of a Type I NES, according to the notation of Sapsis et al.14 This nonlinear stiffness is adjustable and can be set within a large range of values by changing the diameter of the steel wire used and adjusting the distance between the NES and the blocks used to fix the wire, which can be even extended outside the limits of the slab by using a rail system. The inherent damping of the NES is quite low; consequently, the damping of the NES was increased by attaching rubber seals to the ends of the bearing and filling the internal compartment where the ball bearings contact the rail with oil. Because the seals contained the oil within the bearing with minimal losses, the NES could be used multiple times without substantial degradation of the damping. Figure 21.
Nonlinear energy sink.

In order to calibrate models used to compare the analytical and experimental results, an identified model of the NES was required. To perform this identification, the restoring force surface technique was utilized.21 In this technique, an experimentally estimated restoring force is used as a basis to fit an assumed model of the restoring force based on the states of the system. For this application, the assumed model of the restoring force is calculated from free vibration equation of motion with a generic nonlinear stiffness and linear damping of the form (69)

To implement this, the NES was hit; then, using an accelerometer, the response was measured. With a known NES mass and the free vibration acceleration response of the system after the hit, the nonlinear restoring force can be estimated. This acceleration response was then integrated to compute the velocity and displacement of the NES. With these values used in a curve fit of the system, the unknown parameters bNES, kNES, and α can be estimated. An example of the time history of the restoring force estimated from the acceleration response and the restoring force from the fit model is seen in Figure 22. Using this technique and multiple trials, the identified model parameters of the NES configuration used in the experimental testing presented in this article are identified as (70) Figure 22.
Estimated nonlinear restoring force for experimental results and fitted model.

sec.title: Data acquisition
sec.p:
Testing of this structure was performed at the Smart Structures Technology Laboratory at the University of Illinois, where a servo-motor powered uniaxial shake table with a 457.2 × 457 mm2 table was used to test the structure. The command input for the base motion was a step change. As illustrated in Figure 23, the base acceleration is characterized by a short, but finite time duration and afterwards the system undergoes free vibration conditions. The excitation was assumed to be completed when the base acceleration remained below a threshold value of 1 m/s2. In this record, the time origin has been chosen to coincide with the termination of the base excitation as identified from this threshold value. As seen in the figure, the base motion initiates at ti = −0.177 s and immediately thereafter is non-negligible, influenced by both the actuator dynamics as well as the potential presence of nonzero coupling from the structure to the base. However, following the above threshold the effect on the structural response is assumed to be small, and is neglected in the analysis. Thus, beyond t = 0 s the structure is assumed to undergo free vibration. For later comparison with numerical simulations, the initial conditions are taken from the position and velocity records at the identified time origin. Figure 23.
Measured base acceleration.

The test setup was instrumented with PCB 3701G3FA3G capacitive accelerometers, placed on the primary structure's base, first, and second floors and, when applicable, the NES. Representative acceleration measurements for the structure are shown in Figure 24. Again, the time origin has been chosen to coincide with the initiation of the free response for the structure and is marked with the vertical dashed line. In Figure 24(b), the acceleration of the structure during the base excitation is emphasized, illustrating the response of the structure to the base excitation. Following this initial interval, the response decays under free vibration conditions as shown in Figure 24(a). Figure 24.
Measured acceleration records for the structure.

sec.title: Experimental response and analysis
sec.p: With the acquisition of the acceleration measurements described above, the velocity and displacement of the structure were obtained in MATLAB by numerical quadrature using the trapezoidal method. In each case a 4th-order Butterworth high-pass filter was used with a cutoff frequency of 0.20 Hz, implemented with the MATLAB command filtfilt. This served to reduce the effects of numerical drift on the integration. The analysis was performed using the modal coordinates q, as identified from the modal properties of the physical structure in the absence of the NES. In particular, given the experimental acceleration records for each mass, defined as x··=[x··1 x··2]T, the modal accelerations are defined as (71)

In Figure 25, the acceleration, velocity, and displacement of the system are shown. Specifically, the response of modes 1 and 2 are shown in Figure 25(a) and (b), while the response of the NES is shown in Figure 25(c). The modal decomposition used to analyze the response clearly captures the dominant response of the system. The modal frequencies are evident in Figure 25(a) and (b) and during the later times, when the amplitude of the NES is small (t ∼ 4 s) each mode responds as a single degree-of-freedom underdamped linear oscillator. Figure 25.
Experimental response.

In Figure 26, the experimentally derived phase portraits for modes 1 and 2 of the structure are shown. The response begins at the origin as the base excitation is applied and undergoes a significant transient motion, followed by a long duration of free vibration. The identified state where the free response begins is identified with an open circle for each mode. Note that the response following this initial excitation oscillates as the response decays in energy. Figure 26.
Experimentally derived phase portraits.

sec.title: Effective measures of damping
sec.p: The response of the structure is described in terms of the modal coordinates and energies, and the presence of the NES serves to not only dissipate energy but also couple together these structural modes, allowing for a redistribution of energy in the system. The effective measures given in equation (38) characterize the instantaneous stiffness and damping in the system and account for the coupling of the NES to each linear structural mode. Moreover, these effective measures based only on measured time series and are suited to both simulation and experimental results.

The identified effective measures from the experimental data are shown in Figure 27 for two different values of NES stiffness, as well as for the system with the NES locked in place. In this latter case, the effective stiffness is low and is approximately independent of the initial energy in the system. This measure thus represents the intrinsic damping present in the experimental primary system. Figure 27.
Experimentally identified effective damping versus initial energy.

The energy dissipation induced by the NES significantly varies with the initial energy present in the structure. For low initial energies, the effective damping is low, approaching the intrinsic structural damping present in the system. As this initial energy is increased, a maximum effective damping is obtained, before decreasing with further increases in energy. The energy that leads to the optimal effective damping depends on the stiffness of the NES, and the optimal energy decreases with increasing stiffness. However, note that the effective damping obtained for this optimal energy is relatively independent of the stiffness. This is consistent with the results from the numerical simulations of the two degree-of-freedom system.

Finally, in Figure 28, the response of the experimental system in terms of the linear structural modes is shown in the presence of the NES (solid line) and with the NES locked (dashed line) to provide no energy transfer and damping. The NES significantly enhances the damping observed in both modes and leads to increased energy dissipation in the system. Figure 28.
Experimental response; NES active, solid; NES locked, dashed.

sec.title: Comparison with simulation
sec.p:
The experimental results can be compared to the behavior predicted from the numerical simulations, using the identified parameters of both the linear primary system given in equation (42) and the NES given in equation (70). In Figure 29, the experimentally measured displacements are shown with the numerical predictions from the simulation model. The experimental response is shown dashed while the simulation results are denoted with the solid line. In the simulations, the initial conditions are identified from the experimentally observed free response, as described above, and are marked with the small open circles at t = 0. In addition, the response of the experimental structure during the interval of base excitation is shown for t < 0. We note that for the experimental record shown, mode 1 dominates the response. Figure 29.
Comparison between experimental and simulation responses; experimental, solid, simulation, dashed.

The initial agreement between the experimental and simulation data is excellent. The interaction between the NES and the structure can be characterized in three phases, i, namely an initial capture into resonance between the NES and the structure, ii, followed by sustained resonance locking between the primary structure and the NES, and iii, ending by escape from resonance by the NES. The initial interval is associated with changes in the energy of the NES. Because of the essential nonlinearity, the frequency of the NES depends strongly on its energy. The energy in the NES increases until its inherent frequency matches that of the dominant structural mode. Once these frequencies match, the system moves into phase ii, whereby the linear primary system and the NES are locked in resonance. During this phase, energy can be readily transferred from the structure to the NES, and is dissipated in the attachment. Finally, when this resonance condition can no longer be sustained the NES escapes from resonance. The simulation and experimental results match well during the initial two phases, and their differences are only significant in terms of the time at which the resonance condition is lost. The escape from resonance is clearly sensitive to unmodeled dynamics and parameter estimation errors. However, the simulation results adequately describe the response of the experimental system during these initial two phases, when the energy is largest.

The correspondence between the experimental and simulation results, as described by the effective damping, is shown in Figure 30. The qualitative agreement between the simulation and experimentally observed effective damping coefficient is excellent. Finally, the response of the lightly damped structure is driven by the underlying dynamics of the undamped system. The wavelet transform of the experimental response, identifying the frequency content of the data, is shown in Figure 31 as a function of the instantaneous energy. When superimposed on the frequency–energy plots of the analytical model, it is seen that the experimental response follows the structure of the frequency–energy plots of the undamped system. Figure 30.
Experimentally identified effective damping versus initial energy. Figure 31.
Experimental system, Type I NES: Wavelet transforms of the relative displacement between the attachment and primary system.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study has formulated general equations of motion for a linear primary system attached to NES. The response of the vibrational modes of the structure and the effect of the NES are studied through the use of effective measures of damping and frequency, developed previously by Sapsis et al.14 These measures are based only on the time response of the modal displacement and velocity, and are therefore applicable to both simulation and experimental data. The effectiveness of these measures is then illustrated on a two degree-of-freedom linear system, and it is shown that these measures can indeed capture the general dissipation observed in the response. Moreover, these measures can be used to study the influence of the NES parameters on its ability to rapidly dissipate energy when coupled to the linear primary system. In a more general context, based on the fact that the effective damping and stiffness measures discussed herein are based on direct post-processing of measured time series, they can be applied to assess the efficacy of more general (active or passive) shock mitigation designs with smooth or non-smooth characteristics. The effective measures can then assess the capacity of these designs to reduce the energy of different modes of the system.

Indeed, we performed optimization studies producing NES designs that maximize the effective damping measure for a given type of NES. The optimized designs lead to effective shock mitigation of the primary system considered. The methodology can be applied to optimize the design of a general class of multi-degree-of-freedom or flexible systems with essentially nonlinear attachments for effective shock mitigation. For the physical system, the performance as measured by the effective damping depends on both the nonlinear stiffness coefficient of the NES as well as the initial energy in the system. However, through the nondimensionalization, these two quantities are interrelated, and in this study the nondimensional stiffness coefficient is set to unity without loss of generality. Thus, the design optimization is performed on the nondimensional system of equations represented by equations (30) to (32), and subsequently used to identify the optimal values for the dimensional parameters of the system.

Experimental validation of the effective damping measure was provided with a primary two-floor experimental structure with essentially nonlinear attachments on its top floor. Ongoing and future work is focused on the experimental design and implementation of the proposed strongly nonlinear attachments for a six-story structure, together with the corresponding effective damping measures to optimizing the shock mitigation properties of these novel designs. The experimental results reproduce the theoretical predictions and demonstrate the efficacy of using essentially nonlinear attachments for shock mitigation.
